query: What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?
relevant_summary: Evidence relevant to dietary enrichment for captive primates includes: Feeding individuals in social groups was associated with an enrichment task taking less time to complete compared to feeding alone, and monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter when groupmates were present [1343]. Providing cut branches (browse) such as stinging nettles led captive gorillas to use processing skills similar to those of wild gorillas when foraging [1332]. Presenting food in puzzle feeders decreased food sharing, increased foraging behaviour and tool use, increased time spent feeding, reduced inactivity, and also increased aggression in some cases [1318]. No evidence was captured on the effects of providing nectar (including artificial nectar) to primates [1331]. No evidence was captured on the effects of using automated feeders for primates [1341].
